content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												Towns is an addictive little game. Sure, it's not finished yet, but if you're one of those who enjoy building stuff and watching your world grow, it can be fun. I find it amusing that of all the games I have, this indie title is the one that has clocked the most hours for me.I hope that the developers pick up the development pace and finish it, and if there is a feature I would like see implemented, it would be the possibility of manually equipping visiting heroes with gear. They tend to arrive with primitive equipment and forcing them to replace it is so much work that I have not even bothered. The result is a dungeon cluttered by the remains of heroes who blithely bumbled past that Armor of Immortality or Longsword of Instant Death you lovingly crafted for them. Serves them right, I suppose.

content:
Posted: April 19, 2014
												Bought this over a year ago, and I loved it then (83 hrs). I've read about the new updates, and I can't wait to play it again.Towns can be difficult to learn at the beginning of the game. It has a deep level of complexity due to how flexible it is for player building. You do not get complete control over your villagers. Rather, you place a series of instruction for your villagers to follow. As is typical for town building games, your villagers can be pretty dumb sometimes, but that is all part of the fun. You think that you are safe to leave your people to work on the things that you assign them, and sometimes, things go horribly wrong. I've had several cities that have failed horribly, but I have no problems restarting. It just gives me more delivery and more fun.

												The concept of the game is that you are the town that supports the heroes that explore the caves beneath it. A bit of a twist on the adventure game. I personally turn it into Sparta. All the men and women of my town are in armor and have weapons. I enjoy sending 50+ soldiers into the dungeon to clear it myself at times. Overall this game can on some level play without you and does at later levels when you are stable, micromanaging chores out to the towns folk. If you like building, fighting and don't mind the graphics. You may enjoy this game. If you purchased this game, check out these 2 tutorials that may help.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												Towns is an addictive little game. Sure, it's not finished yet, but if you're one of those who enjoy building stuff and watching your world grow, it can be fun. I find it amusing that of all the games I have, this indie title is the one that has clocked the most hours for me.I hope that the developers pick up the development pace and finish it, and if there is a feature I would like see implemented, it would be the possibility of manually equipping visiting heroes with gear. They tend to arrive with primitive equipment and forcing them to replace it is so much work that I have not even bothered. The result is a dungeon cluttered by the remains of heroes who blithely bumbled past that Armor of Immortality or Longsword of Instant Death you lovingly crafted for them. Serves them right, I suppose.

content:
Posted: April 19, 2014
												Bought this over a year ago, and I loved it then (83 hrs). I've read about the new updates, and I can't wait to play it again.Towns can be difficult to learn at the beginning of the game. It has a deep level of complexity due to how flexible it is for player building. You do not get complete control over your villagers. Rather, you place a series of instruction for your villagers to follow. As is typical for town building games, your villagers can be pretty dumb sometimes, but that is all part of the fun. You think that you are safe to leave your people to work on the things that you assign them, and sometimes, things go horribly wrong. I've had several cities that have failed horribly, but I have no problems restarting. It just gives me more delivery and more fun.

												Most RPGs take from the "you are the hero" vantage point, but I never thought to be the one who controlled the town/village that housed the adverturers, and I didn't expect to like it so much.I'm not sure why but this game was a lot of fun when I was playing it. number of helpful: 0 of 5 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 4, 2015
												A Isometric town management game where instead of you playing the RPG, you are the RPG. Instead of giving quests and farming and such, you are all of these things, commanding your heros where to go. It is a completely different experience than most other town simulators. Unfortunately, the developers have abandoned the game, thus it will not be developed further. It is a shame to see this happen, especially since the game's reputation took a big hit because of it, but that doesn't stop me from recommending it.Bottom Line: This game is great fun if you want to be the one who gives out the quests and sends potential heros on adventures, instead of the one doing all of the work as one person! This is great fun if you also like managing cities. The music while repetitive suits the style of the game, the mechanics are serviceable, and the graphics pay homage to games like the Ceasar Series, which look great! I recommend this game to those who are interested!

content:
Posted: February 27, 2013
												I got this game with the impression that it was going to be like Minecraft. When I started playing it, I realized just how wrong I really was. Towns really gives the impression that you are playing a minecraft clone from a bird's eye view, but what you soon learn is that amidst all of the building and gathering you would expect to have to do, there lies even more. Managing your citizens happiness, raising livestock, and creating automated systems to gather and plant crops, all of this just to skim the surface. As a game still being constructed, Towns has a very promising future. Highly recommend this series to anyone who likes the Sims franchise or any castle building games.

content:
Posted: December 1, 2013
												This is a great game for someone willing to dedicate time to understanding it. The tutorials are rather poor and most of the learning is done by understanding what little the tutorials teach and applying it elsewhere. The game is a lot of fun and offers some replayability. It's a great challenge that I enjoy. I know there's a lot of bad reviews, but I honestly don't think these people gave their best effort in trying it out, and the game improves greatly with each update; most of the reviews were done before the game's main components were complete. I think it's a great game to play, but it takes a certain kind of player to enjoy it. I'd recommend trying the demo out first to make sure you like the game.

number of helpful: 8 of 22 people (36%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												This is a fun little town simulation game with challenging gameplay and lots of facets to it.  I have definitely enjoyed it, despite the fact that I have gotten stuck numerous times trying to figure out how to progress which leads me to the game's problems.  This is still in development, and it shows.  A lot of aspects aren't explained very well and a lot of things about your villagers are hard to control.  For example, to get more villagers your villagers need to be happy.  Happiness is influenced by numerous factors, how nice their rooms are, what variety of things they have to eat, what kind of decorations they have to look at but also how much work they have to do.  If they have too much work they get stressed but if they have too little they get bored, there's no way to tell villagers how much of their time to spend relaxing and how much working (aside from a somewhat unpredictable job assignment system).  There is a great community forum with a lot of mods for the game and that helps but I cant help but wish they had more streamlining.Pros:Neat ConceptGood MechanicsTons of replayability (due to procedural generation)Fun and not overcomplicated simCons:Less-than-optimal controlsPoor in-game instructions

Posted: September 25, 2014
												I've owned Towns for quite a while now and although some poor decisions of the developer have thrown a lot of flak it’s way recently, I’d like to say that the game itself is still very enjoyable.Throughout its development, Towns has been all over the place in the performance department but it has never been unplayable. There is ample content for many many hours of creation and enjoyment and even since the last time I played there has been some significant addition to the game. The UI is very functional, the art style is charming, and compared to the titles which inspired it, Towns is extremely accessible for newcomers to the isometric, town building, minion ordering.. micro managing... I’ll try that again- Towns is extremely accessible for newcomers to the Dwarf Fortress genre of game.

number of helpful: 52 of 115 people (45%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 18, 2013
												I caught it on sale for real cheap.  At first I thought I wasted money on this game and It took awhile, but I am really into it now.  The paths to success are not obvious and it can appear extremely simplistic at first but there is a much deeper game to be found.  Even in the current state of the game you can build a fully functioning economy.  Its kind of like playing with legos, except you have to keep your people alive and obvious oversights can lead to starvation or running into momsters that will happily eat them for dinner.It is not for everyone, the basic functions are all there.  There are some features half implemented but the modding community seems to have taken care fo the holes (I am not currently using any mods).  I have no doubt the finish product would keep me playing even longer than i already have... but it will require some patience for this game to get there... if it ever does...  If all the the above issues dont turn you off and you want to Alpha test the foundations of what could be an amazing game I'd buy it.  Like I said before you can build a functioning town. However,  DO NOT EXPECT A FINISH PRODUCT YOU WILL BE DISSAPOINTED.

number of helpful: 6 of 18 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 24, 2013
												It's nice after you get into it. No proper tutorial makes a bit hard in the beginning, but no deal-breaker. This isn't the short 2-hour game, you can really spend time there, it's a crude version of Sims combined with Minecraft in strategy mode where you command a lot of "minecraft players", your citizens. The commands are leaned towards automation so you dont have so much direct control, but enough for sure.Note: this game was supposedly made by one programmer and one artist and the programmer has allegedly quit this project (and there's rumors this project was never a high priority thing for him) so dont expect the bugs to be fixed. I did enjoy the game, but that's because I like to discover new things, even find out the game mechanics instead of having them explained to me. Anyone who feels differently, you shouldn't buy this game because there's a lot finding-out to do with game mechanics, and that's most likely not gonna change.The game mechanics work though, it's just a long try & fail process often. But you can also make up for your failures, like build new if buildings get destroyed (they shouldn't), get new villagers if old ones die (how compassionate) and even buy new animals from the visiting vendors.I feel this game has a lot of potential, but is poorly polished. I dont know how much the developers make with this, but they could make 10 times more bucks if they polished it, hired the crew and decided to listen to people.

number of helpful: 5 of 16 people (31%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 19, 2013
												It may be a bad game to most of you, and I consider it challenging, but there is a way around many of these problems. You can find a way to talk to the devs on your own. Also, I don't like the fact that there is no "Creative" mode, to where you don't have to worry about your problems. I really do think there is hope for Towns.

												I feel strongly that this game has it right in a lot of old school ways. Yes, its graphically lacking, however whats happening is pure gold. All of the content we have grown to love as gamers exists in this piece of software. City building, creation, leveling, crafting, exploration and dungeon crawling all in a randomly generated package? content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												This game gets alot of underserved flak. Yeah they didnt develop it as throughly as they had said they would, however its is fun and functional. I played 55 hours and never felt the games was broken. I personally never encountered any major bugs either. I play Gnomoria as well and they both have their strong points. Honestly for $20 you can have them both and have tons of gameplay hours. Towns has its own special like points that make it a very worthwhile experience if you are interested in the genre.

number of helpful: 4 of 14 people (29%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 24, 2014
												This game is pretty much a DF extra-lite. Legos with monsters. It's not difficult, but there are city building and management aspects. You need to establish a food and resource hub so you can build a bigger city and get more "Townies" as they're called, then dig underground, build a tavern, attract some heroes, and dig deeper for better resources.The goal of the game isn't to reach some unknown boss. I'm not even sure there is an endgame with Towns. I never reached the maximum depth because I never held it as a main objective. I played this game because I have a god complex and want to create a thriving city and watch my citizens thrive by my grace and strategic expertise.The sieges are kind of a joke, but they're a good source of spiderite and goo. My only wish is that the devs went more in depth with the town defense aspect of this game, but it's no big deal. I have ~100hrs in this game, so I think I got my money's worth.Personally, I don't understand all the backlash this game got. I got this game on sale roughly a year and a half ago for ~2.50(?). Worth every penny, given my playtime. I'm pretty sure if I knew how much time I'd spend playing it, I'd drop 10 bucks on it in a heartbeat.I think a lot of the anger has to do with entitlement. Games in this genre now adays (legos with monsters: DF, Minecraft, Terraria) are being released as full games, and the devs are devoted enough to the games to continue to release content. I don't think Towns needs to release more content. I think it's fine how it is. Some people may not think it's worth 10 bucks. To me, it is, but I'm 100% certain it's worth at least 5. Then again, I didn't enter this expecting updates. They appear more as a pleasant surprise for me.

People are getting♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off that the devs are complete♥♥♥♥♥♥and in some way that is true, but they had to stop developing the game becuase they ran out of money and a lot of people complain that the devs are sellouts cause they think they walked away from this with 2 miilion dollars blah blah blah what ever your reason is to hop on the hate train is your reason. I have played this game for 35 hours and my brother has played it too for about 40+ and after we stop playing towns me and him both felt it was a fun good game with some bugs of course. content:
Posted: March 30, 2013
												This game is awesome. I really like the concept of building a town that heroes visit, and then having the heroes clear out the dungeon so your villagers can mine. While there is a limit to the amount of playtime you can get from one city (It's not necessarily limited, but there will be a point when you've done everything), it's really fun while it lasts, and takes a ood 50+ hours to dig every layer of the dungeon and kill everything and have a full roster of townies (villagers) etc. And you can always start a new Town! The tutorial is utter crap at the moment in time I'm writing this, so don't depend on it, I'd just watch a few YouTube Playthroughs, as that's how I learned how to play it. But fo' shizzles, this is a great game, and a great buy.

number of helpful: 3 of 12 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 28, 2014
												This deserves deeper analysis that I'm about to give it, but this is one of my favorite "small game" experiences as of late.  When describing Towns to people, I decided it was like telling 10 people how to play minecraft… but without the patterned crafting.  So much of minecraft is lived in telling someone where to put something in a 3x3 grid, but in towns you just say "Go make a wooden sword" and they must goto the wiki on their own and look it up.Towns places you in the traditional omniscient 3rd person viewing angle that Christ himself enjoys.   You get a randomly generated world with 11 citizens of your "Town".  You drop orders for what to do, and the citizens go do it.  Chop down all these trees I've moused over.  Harvest this apple tree.  Build this wall.  Dig this tunnel.  Oh crap, there's spiders in that tunnel.  No, no don't die… run away… crap.And then you start a new game and realize there's much more you need to do before you plumb the depths of your little block world.Towns is an impressively deep game where it does not appear to be on the surface.  I mean that literally as well as figuratively as while at the surface of the game it's about Townsperson happiness management (oh yea, they need to be happy, not over worked and if you can manage that, you'll get more people showing up in town… that's an important mechanic that I didn't think of until now… see… deep) and setting up replenishable resources so everyone doesn't starve and you've got plenty of wood for that epic barbarian castle you just dreamt up.  Dig down only a couple layers and there's combat to be had.  Not super impressive combat, just your people wiggling at the beast until one of them makes this strange death noise.  You can't control the combat at all.  Soldiers can be designated, even set on patrol routes, but they intervene somewhat rarely which makes taking them off labor to just stand around with the best sword you've made so far a little useless.Again, this game goes so much deeper than I'm giving it credit for in this review… suffice to say, it's quite enjoyable. If you like economy heavy RTS, dwarf-likes or civilization games give it a whirl.  I recommend buy-in at $10, but that's only because it's a little bit of a gamble as to wether you'll like it.  I'd be willing to give this game $25, but that's knowing how much I enjoy it after playing it for hours.4 Visuals8 Gameplay8 SlantOverall : 67

number of helpful: 3 of 12 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 10, 2014
												First to say, I have spent many hours playing towns. MANY hours, and most of the 'towns' i created ended up bugged or lag-based on all accounts or glitched on load. So many faults, but i found it most likely i was building or mining something that was 'illegal' and had in previous versions faulted the game. New not good enough last ever update fixed some of the errors. My latest game or town i created, makes me rank this game AS WORTH HAVING, since no new updates are ever going to be created, possible it might be modified at some point some where on if... possibly nothing if or possible. The game recent, the only possible idea that could make this game work is more glabol control.Point 1,IF! if the game had an 'unlock all objects' key, which would be including those on top such as 2nd story roof and up, and scroll across the map, and a ignore all unlocked items, fading them from view so that you could rebuild as you expand, say 20 townies later on you might want to change the look of your town so that happiness is added more fluently(happiness draws in more townies, tip block all roads with fences and 1 block openings still fenced-in although the spot is used with a high happiness decoration, all townies must take the fensed roads, and always gain happiness, the fences should block line of sight too, for all other lower decorations that make your town unique looking and worth creating and blocking sight of other unhappy such stuff [corpses lol]!) so to wrap up point 1, once you build something expect to keep it, even if u realize you wasted a whole lotta space with little useless alleys that u got to block off anyways or whatever your reason. as well as each building wall block needs to be clicked to unlocked(why no auto unlock key?), It is fun to create brick by brick so to speak until you have clicked thousands and thousands of times, and you only have maybe 20 fully furnished and roofed structures(like 15% of the map if you build BIG), but where is the schematic page, where you can create and paste what you want.. I MEAN COME ON WTF stupid person could not add a schematic setup so that you do not neED to place brick by brick every damn BRICK. You might not understand the awesome happiness system, i do i love it, as is I gain 4 townies every few minutes until i reach about 100(ofcourse the townies live in unwalled unroofed houses with a single high happiness object each, only until later do i now design my town), maybe 2 hours of playing saying that at some point(in the past sometimes my game just would not load, or whateverbug at the time, since update final ive had almost no issues with bugs, sometimes lag after a while and i just have to restart towns game and its fixes) some point i dont lose my game and ok and i cap off my residents because i am tired of making the same structures to fit each part of my town, i make 80% the same with different base or roof designs. END POINT 1.Point 2.WTF my townies die for the most stupid reasons, and when one dies the rest follow, it takes 30 seconds for 1 high level enemy to sneak past a new hedge that grants access into your town to murder all of your townies before a single soldier townie arrives. The soldier system is laughable, the level system is worse, the townies ability to form soldier groups looks near identicle and stands on the screen right next to the 'return townies to civi status' and if you do that that once soldier loses all levels and expereienced gain. So two hours in my level 30 warrior reverts to lvl 1 cause i missclicked. Do i reload? wait i just cleared that floor and salvaged some structures (I do not want to reclick the structures brick by brick to move together to add more what/ever is needed floor layout). Its a bummer, the soldiers four options are useful, well 1 is useful the 'patrol script', say you have 3 soldiers and a single patrol point, at least one soldier will be there if that single spot needs defending. So you can bundle your town opening with your dungeon opening and that one soldier can last until heros or townies or your actual soldiers get off thier fat behinds and leave the dining room to fight or patrol is what it is. What could be added, is a auto level for all characters based on time they have been in your town, or gain experience for all townies, but soldiers gain double. As is the soldier usage can be annoying, i try to make 1/8 to 1/4 townies into soldiers since i play on the hardest difficulty and i do survive most instances of invasion.Point FinalAs was townies die, or the game glitches because some townie is trying to fly off a roof, or climb three spaces high for that first piece of stone or ore and cannot reach, that does now with the last update usually cancel all actions for a townie that cannot reach or interact with a ai-script(farming,mining,building) and does not cause too much of an issue. Unless that townie is behind that 3 story wall just too far to reach the ground, and dies of starvation, scaffolding!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! WTF WHY is there no auto build SCAFFOLDING when something is just out of reach, or why start up the map with stupid stone bricks i need to mine on the surface of the map stacked up like some tower. REcent update added scaffolds decay after time, so no need to delete them unless that immediate space is needed, wait a while and the scaffolding will fade away from the game, its kind of cool getting a 3 story structure up and watching it unfold as teh scaffolding decays away and reveals the time you spent clicking each brick into place, each window painstackingly placed. It makes it worth it too, if like I do often I show off my towns online or to friends i say hey look what i spent four hours making.( I got one friend to buy the game, and after about ten hours of playing he had about 15 townies, i wanted to cry) The game has no introduction, as well as no explanation, examples being bone torch=1 happiness, harp=2 happiness, decorated wall= go ---- yourself(i think to myself) it does not add any worth while happiness as it does override all better happiness objects. EXTRA POINT------------------------------- MAKE ALL WALLS,optional decorated(same look but with makes happiness) and costs say 1 extra material of a single needed of a single variety.Back TO last POINT of interest------------- Play this game only if you understand ai scripts and basic map editor knowledge as once you get the hang of it, its totally easy to play even on the hardest of difficulties, my favorite too because you do not get stupid molerats stealing your food, instead just some ogres to fight. Yes i recommend this game to anyone who has a brain and enjoyings a challenge, it is unfinished, good chance what there is is all there will ever be in this game. So far, I have yet to find a single piece of useful information on the forums and online searches, you need to learn from the game, find the flaws and single them out.My personal example of playEither map type,FIRST ACTION-------------- CREATE 16 resident tiles 3x3 each, wait 30 seconds, you get more townies to start the game with!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!SECOND ACTION----------- Make into soldiers all townies and hunt down all of the monsters on the surface of the map, no not leave a single monster alive. Change all but the best soldier(based on stats, only hp and offense matter) back into townies(equip the townies who are your lumber workers with the dropped weapons from the monsters. ENJOY a fruitful start to a great town.

number of helpful: 3 of 12 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 15, 2014
												The Towns Tragedy: A Case Study in Early AccessSo first off, I recommend this game... but just barely. It's pretty fun for the money, and you'll get pretty engaged managing your little town. It has a lot of complexity, but not very accessible... be prepared for a little front loading on tutorials. The features are a bit haphazardly put together, but you can still cobble together a pretty good experience out of it. The tragedy here is that the developer quit working on the game before it was completed. In all honesty, I wish Towns had been where it is now when it was put up for early access. Developers calling it quits or settling for "almost good enough" is getting pretty tiring in the independant market.

content:
Posted: October 30, 2013
												Great simulation game. You manage harvesting, planting, storing, building, mining and exploring, etc. Very steep learning curve, which is nice. Took me around five hours and as many restarts just to achieve a self-sustainable colony. Great music and lovely graphics.Edit: addictive as HELL. Multiple times I've played for just one more cycle of harvest/replant, well into the night, well past my bedtime.Somethings I'd like to see added/improved: - bigger maps - more fluid animations (on your Townies) - more in-game tools to fix things, change things (create Animal in case you wipe out a population, etc)Those are just suggestions, not criticisms.

content:
Posted: December 15, 2013
												It seems the devs have basically stopped working on this game because they are "Burned out".  There are some bugs and things that should have been addressed by now. That being said I still feel this game is worth your time and money. There are many negative reviews and most of the ones I have read are accurate to a point on their critisizm. Regardless of what you read this game is VERY much playable and fun. It is also easy to mod. I am not happy about the development at this point but I would still recommend this game for anyone who likes to build and manage a city or town.

content:
Posted: February 13, 2014
												I have a feeling this game will be hit or miss with people.  If being thrown into an environment where you're just left to build and figure stuff out appeals to you, then you'll love it.  If it looks like butts to you and you can't be bothered to figure out the gameplay mechanics , you'll probably hate it and uninstall immediately.I got roped into this pretty hard just because of the initial learning curve.  My first few towns got ruined immediately by starvation or murloc invasions, but I stuck with it and figured it out and was, I feel, rewarded for my efforts.  Building a town to house heroes is pretty kickass but then on top of that getting to manage the many levels of dungeons below is pretty cool also.  I've sunk a buttload of time into this game, like 120+ hours, and still don't want to stop until I clear the 18th level of the dungeon.   It does get pretty repetetive at 100 hours... but what game doesn't?Love it.

number of helpful: 3 of 12 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 10, 2013
												A game with a lot of potential that really falls quite short at the time.  The concept is cool; build a town and let adventurers clear out the dungeon for you.  On paper it all seems great but in practice not so much.  While the devs admit the game is still being updated (and they have been updating it) there is still a lot of work to be done.  One redeeming fact is you can edit game files to modify things in the game to make it more enjoyable.  I recommend this game because it is a really neat concept, but i'd wait for more patching and maybe a price drop to make sure you are getting a complete product to get your money's worth.

number of helpful: 11 of 29 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												Wow, my last review was huge.Before you buy, (who is looking to buy this game anymore??) be sure to check out various reviews and decide for yourself what you expect.  Yeah, there are bugs, the game is unfinished.  At launch, it was one of very few city building sims on Steam that had that element of RTS/Hero management.  Banished for the same money is a near-AAA experience, so don't go buying this game unless you own that or Cities: Skylines.  If you are into resource and development sims then Factorio is infinitely a better choice.  There are others, but I'm only naming ones I have a lot of experience with.Towns can be considered an early Java template game, it doesn't stray far from what you usually see in typical browser games, but I love it and that's that.  This game has a much better experience than Towncraft, an abandonware game that is way worse of a consumer-trust relationship.Make sure you educate yourself if you're actually consider spending full price on this game.  There are hundreds of games on Steam that would probably be better suited for that amount.  If you want a unique glimpse into what was one of the "founders" of how Steam became the conglomerate of early access/scam gaming, you won't be disappointed.  And hey, once you get past the bugs and logic-defying mechanics, you might even enjoy playing it a little bit.  I sure as hell did, and that was back when this game was front and center in the Steam Drama world.

number of helpful: 2 of 10 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 5, 2014
												ONLY GET THIS GAME IF YOU LIKE DYING AND A CHALLENGE.It is not that bad of a game. If you give it enough time. If you are wanting to build an elaborate fortess with 5 stories and everything perfectly place in it, you will get mad and quite the game. Instead look at it as a survival game mod with ever increasing sieges that force you to explore the depths of dungeons so you can equip your villagers with good enough weapons to survive the 200 spiders that spone inside your base. It does have many bugs to it: having to set flags at every square to explore a dungeon, a villager ignoring your minimum level setting and going into the 5 floor just to pickup a set of bones, the over bulky food production (only efficient way is to eat T1 food that only fills 20%), the "heroes" that drag dungeon monsters into your city, the glitchy animal farming, the complete lack of certain resources on maps (excluding that random unreachable piece of coal placed floating ontop of the lake). But these are all part of the random events and part of the challenge. Every time you get killed off, you learn a new aspect of the game. The reason they don't explain much of the tutorial is becuase they want to you figure it out in the game.It has a lot more depth into the game: dealing with traders, forming an army to defend sieges, creating a badger areana, wood working, smithing, fishing, glass blowing, vanities (cosmetics), inlisting heroes, killing monsters (orcs, goblins, ogers, giant, trolls, ect), a death cycle for villagers (disease, disposal of corpses/ wraiths), farming, pastry making, complex item system, and a lot more that you have to discover. But you do not see these with just playing for the first 5-10 hours and calling it crap.

number of helpful: 2 of 10 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 8, 2012
												An awesome mixture of Minecraft, SimCity and roleplaying scheme! Start from pretty much nothing, command your people to harvest wood, gather apples, grow wheat and afterwards bake a bread out of it. Crafting is as necessary part of this game as it is in Minecraft. In addition to this, you should really take it as a serious matter to equip swords and armor to some of your townsfolk, because if you face a vicious tree, a ghost, a spider or anything between them, you're pretty much dead. By setting your military men to patrol around your village when building it towards to the greatest empire on earth, you should feel pretty safe! An awesome title with a little learning curve, but when you get a hang of it, you wont stop advancing further and further!

number of helpful: 1 of 8 people (13%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 13, 2014
												[EDIT] Holy crap they released a patch Apr 2014 and are taking suggestions for v15. It's alive!Objectively, the reviews below saying "not recommended" are correct. The game is really not finished, and given it has an development for many years, and has not seen an update in a while, and the developer statement that he is "burned out", I would not expect any more updates.With that said, I still spent an enjoyable month or so playing this game. Coming from Dwarf Fortress and wanting something a little prettier, this game provides a nice twist on the genre, rather than mining you "dig too deep" by hiring heroes who explore dungeons.It provides an interesting and detailed tech tree, one of the best workshop designs I have seen in any such game (you place zones for workshops and then crafting stations within zones).That said, I am obsessed with this genre and desperate for other games in it. If you want to try something like this but with active development and far more polished, I highly recommend Gnomoria (and keeping an eye on Stonehearth and Clockwork Empires).I would still recommend this game, although given it is unlikely to see any updates I would personally want to see the price knocked down a little given its incomplete state.I really hope the new developer breathes new life into this game, but I feel like once the game gets into a negative feedback cycle developers have little incentive to do so -- when everyone is panning your game on Steam and no updates have been released for a year and a half, what is your incentive to continue working on it?Even if you decide not to buy, I would keep an eye on this game just in case things change.This game has a tremendous amount of potential, and is farther long than many games in the genre.

number of helpful: 1 of 8 people (13%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 7, 2014
												Game is a great survivial game, it puts all the surviving factors together, starvation, wild life, etc, aswell with traits that took place back then and even today, including Rivalry, Citizenship, and currency. Although it has good factors, it has some bad ones too.  The game seems to bore you a bit too easily, and the randomly generated spawns can quite frequently put you right on top of a biom with hostile natural life. I have 25 hours on it, and i've had it for nearly a year. In my 25 hours of gameplay, i've never figured out how to get Iron, and make needed tools. I try to build a town, but every time I try to, my citizens starve to death, or Ghosts kill them. To fix this, I focused a TON more on food, but that didn't stop the Ghost of Heroes past's from attacking and slaughtering all my people. This game does have alot of Pros compared to Cons though, and i highly reccomend it    to any survival type people out there who love to play a survivial, and always ask "Can i build a city on it?" type questions. I would rate it a 8/10 if it was up to me. Graphics might be a bit dissapointing, but if you don't only look at games for their graphics, and just want the fun, this is a good game. I never noticed many bugs, maybe a few, and I seen the comments.

content:
Posted: August 14, 2015
												This game is very challenging, but enjoyable. I do wish there was a way to strengthen your heroes more before you send them to the lower levels (other than raids), but at least they don't stop coming. Sure I had to look up some things on the wiki but it was the same way for everybody for games such as this, or Minecraft, or they had a friend who told them the recipes or the way redstone works and ways you can implement redstone to make something awesome. I hope Towns has more updates in the future to fix certain minor things, but other than that I very much enjoy playing the game. Another plus is how simple mods are done, unlike Minecraft I can get most of the mods I want to work (Not to dog on Minecraft because I love Minecraft too, but the mods are done poorly for it) For towns you just have to drop the mod into the mods file, while Minecraft will make you download other mods to get mods to work. Also Towns has (I think) an official mods website that you can go to, while Minecraft you have to trust your instincts on whether to download said mods. I know there's the wiki and stuff for mods, but when I download them and drop them in the mods file it always crashes my game or just doesn't work. Maybe your experience is different with minecraft and towns, but that is my experience.

number of helpful: 0 of 6 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 10, 2014
												I poured many hours into this game. I will admit that a great deal of them were while I was afk, letting the world run itself, especially if I was in a bit of a recession. Towns as a game is a great idea, and had the potential for greatness in it. It had some fun elements, digging deep into the earth looking for ore, while building a utopia above.It has it's fair share of bugs, and the AI leaves a bit to be desired. Can't tell you how often I've lost an entire village while afk because the guards don't know how to protect the villagers and then go heal themselves properly. Can be a real spirit breaker. As it is, it is playable, and a certain level of fun can certainly be had for this game, but I give you fair warning here:THIS GAME HAS BEEN ABANDONED BY THE DEVELOPERS. That means this product will come to you AS IS, with no thought of change to make note of. It's not terribly expensive, and I've certainly poured enough time into this game to have made it worth the 15 bucks I paid for it, but all in all, you may just end up avoiding this game and try something with a similar touch to it, but is more polished.

number of helpful: 0 of 6 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 31, 2014
												It's odd. All these games that are so clearly very much like Dwarf Fortress just lack almost all of the appeal of Dwarf Fortress. Towns is one of the worst in that regard. The complex, text-based menu system of DF is here replaced by a seemingly MORE complex icon-based menu system.The gameplay is very similar to DF's Fortress Mode, having you build a Town from scratch by harvesting resources from the land and using them to build tools, then using those tools to harvest resources more efficiently, then using THOSE resources to build structures.I can't really put my finger on why DF has such an appeal to me while Towns (which, as stated, is VERY similar in most regards) just doesn't. If you like town-building sims and managing a population, this is a good game. If you don't like complicated menus and long♥♥♥♥♥tutorials to teach you how to use them, try something else.

content:
Posted: August 14, 2015
												This game is very challenging, but enjoyable. I do wish there was a way to strengthen your heroes more before you send them to the lower levels (other than raids), but at least they don't stop coming. Sure I had to look up some things on the wiki but it was the same way for everybody for games such as this, or Minecraft, or they had a friend who told them the recipes or the way redstone works and ways you can implement redstone to make something awesome. I hope Towns has more updates in the future to fix certain minor things, but other than that I very much enjoy playing the game. Another plus is how simple mods are done, unlike Minecraft I can get most of the mods I want to work (Not to dog on Minecraft because I love Minecraft too, but the mods are done poorly for it) For towns you just have to drop the mod into the mods file, while Minecraft will make you download other mods to get mods to work. Also Towns has (I think) an official mods website that you can go to, while Minecraft you have to trust your instincts on whether to download said mods. I know there's the wiki and stuff for mods, but when I download them and drop them in the mods file it always crashes my game or just doesn't work. Maybe your experience is different with minecraft and towns, but that is my experience.

content:
Posted: October 18, 2014
												Basically if you're a fan of Dwarf Fortress, or think you would enjoy an easier version of DF you will definitely get your moneys worth with this game.  I sank many hours into it after buying it on sale but it's worth even the 14.99 regular price.This game has a LOT of negative reviews simply for the fact that the Devs officially announced that they were ending development on the game.  You can see that hundreds of reviews were posted around the same date they announced they were stopping development   It seems however that they have restarted development.  This game is worth your money even in the unfinished state, but now that development is back on it's even more worth your money.  I would honestly suggest, if at all possible, that someone from the team go through and send a message to all these people that left negative reviews on that basis.  This game has massive potential and I would love to see the community in support again.  Website for the game does appear to be down however.

												I don't like this game too too much. It is pretty grindy. If you like town/city build games and point and click for adventure style games. Then this might be your game. You have to always keep an eye on all of your resources and outposts.EDIT:Since the devs kinda walked away from this game I would not recommend this game if you are kinda into games that get constantly updated like minecraft or starbound or something like that.But still if you just like the idea of managing a city/town and you want a challenge. This is your game, I highly recommend trying to mod this game or make your own mods for this game because some things are not really balanced, such as food.Food is like a really big concern, they should've called it "Don't Starve"... but I guess that name has already been copyrighted...

content:
Posted: April 22
												People, stop reviewing a game in a negative light for the sole reason of it being abandoned. It is childish! So ironic that I see so many reviews stating that they "loved this game early on" and then proceed with something around the lines of "but the developers abandoned it". The fact remains that even as it stands, in an abandoned state, it is still worth playing. I vote it up not because I want to prove a point, nor do I vote it up because I support the developers running off with my money. I vote it up because of the question the "Yes" or "No" asks, "Do you recommend this game?" That yes or no answer is a recommendation for the game, not the developers. This game is well deserving of at least trying it. I played it before it got on Steam for countless hours and enjoyed every second, and also experienced no "bugs" at all. So stop your ♥♥♥♥ing whining over something you can fix and move on.

												Ok so let me give you my review to this game but first lets go to a few mishaps:The developers don't exist anymore or hardly work on this game.The game is hard to understand.The AI are doing what they are told but doing different task because you just don't know how to set them right.Now putting that aside let me give my review:This game is fun! You gotta get resources make sure you have food and armor to keep them safe and healthy.Build a hospital if they are injured. Build each of your villagers a home and add decoration to make them happy to allow more villagers to join in.Build a trade market get resources you have hard time getting from the merchant and sell your resources you been gathering for money.build a tavern with tavern room to get heroes to join the village dig below the cave to allow heroes to explore for more rare ores.Build a animal farm so many bones drop? no problem make armor out of them and build your homes bone are useful material in this game.Keep your villagers happy and give each of them a task so they dont over burden their works if you make them work to hard they will die so careful what action you do to give your villages and watch them prosper.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2012
												Despite almost nothing but horrible reviews, I found myself quite liking this game. Never played Dwarf Fortress, so I'm one of the few who can't really compare this to that. To me, it's like a mashup of Minecraft and Majesty. There's definitely room for improvement, but the developers are saying this is still technically only an alpha build of the game, so if they don't drag their feet and actually listen to feedback from their community, this game could one day go from being a fun little time waster to a truly great game in it's own right. For what it's worth, this is what had it's hooks in my almost nonstop until XCOM Enemy Unknown entered my stable. And then THAT one blasted everything else, including Guild Wars 2, right outta the water. lol

content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												The devs have returned and picked up the game, so I gave it a try!I don't normally play town building games such as this but it seems the perfect blend of a town builder, RPG, and Minecrafting. I was told there is a steep learning curve to play the game and they were not kidding! Although the tutorial is informative, it takes a while to sort out your priorities and get your townies on their feet in order to take full advantage of what the game has to offer! I definitely recommend watching some tutorial videos online before you tackle this game, if only to learn your way around the nav bars. Be prepared to lose a few townies and maybe even start over. And be prepared to spend a lot of time at your PC because this game is highly addicting. If you like RPGs and Minecraft, you'll like this game!

content:
Posted: November 17, 2014
												This is one of my favorite games. Yes, it is difficult to get into at first, how to understand where to put things and hot to make buildings look good. It is a challenge, and for that, I am grateful! This game makes you use your brain to figure out how to overcome obsticals. How to make water go where you want it, and how to prepare for sieges. I love how the people will try to do things together instead of one person trying to do it all alone. And yes, it is difficult and frustrating trying to get more people to your town at first. But don't fret! It does get easier. This game makes you constantly wnt to upgrade your town to make it like a real place, something enjoyable. Although, there are so many things they could do to make it better! When I first played this game on my boyfriends account, I was puzzled. I think I played it for about 6 hours straight just trying to figure the game out. Finally, when it started to make more sense, he was intrigued by it and also wanted to try again, even though he called it stupid because he couldn't get it before. This game has so many possibilities, so many things  you can do, oh and watch out for werepig!!

content:
Posted: November 16, 2014
												It looks like most of the reviews here are just people who buy the game and get mad after a while of playing it, probably starving to death or traveling down into a dungeon. If you're like me, you were digging and lost 20 people when they hit water and drowned in the flooded mine shaft. But this game has come a long way since some of its earliest versions, even before this game was on Steam. The developers really put a lot into making this game better and better, so much that when I found this game on Steam a long time after I played one of the earlier versions on the website, I didn't know what I was doing. There was so much more for me to do and figure out. I would say that this game isn't for everyone, but I personally love this game and respect the developers for making so many improvements. If you're not sure about this game, try watching someone play it on youtube to get a good idea of what the game is all about. I highly recommend this game to my friends and anyone who has the patience to build a beautiful town out of only their natural environment.

												6/10 I had an earlier review of this game in which I was very positive about it despite the lack of development. I'm knocking my score down from 7/10 to 6/10 because although I still occasionally enjoy this game it feels very limited. This game had excellent potential that was never fully fufilled. The difficulty is also very biased. If you lose more than a couple people your first hour playing your town proably won't have enough people to feed itself, protect itself, AND build and expand.I feel I got my moneys-worth from this game, but if you're considering buying it I highly suggest you wait for it to go on sale as I don't forsee it ever having another update, unless for some reason a lot of people suddenly start buying it, and then the devs may become re-interested.I give it a 6/10 because although it's frustrating it can still be enjoyable.

content:
Posted: March 15
												People are so butt-hurt about this game, I don't understand why. I was actually an extremely early supporter of this game, well before it arrived on Steam. I bought it directly through the dev's website, through Paypal. At that early stage of development it had only around 10% of the features that the modern version has. Nothing was animated, sounds and sprites were missing.. there were no buttons, everything worked through these weird broken context menus. Despite all that, I thought it was a really cool game, a grid-based town-builder similar to Dwarf Fortress, except with this additional dungeoneering element. To date I still think this is the best DF-clone that has ever appeared since it's easy to learn, easy to use, and lots of fun. I prefer this to Gnomoria too.People have a lot of complaints about this game, about broken promises or features that were never implemented. Well, I have a different way of looking at it. I've played this game for at least 30 or 40 hours. And it has been extremely fun. It's a really really fun game. It's the perfect game for when you want to play Dwarf Fortress but you want to chill out and take away the complicated bits.So ignore the haters, try the free demo. It's a brilliant game. People say it's not finished, I disagree. If you can spend 30+ hours having crazy fun with a game then it's finished enough in my book.*Note: I played it mostly as the DRM-free version, downloaded from the dev's website, not through steam.*

content:
Posted: July 23, 2014
												TRY THE DEMO! It's free, and believe me - it's the best test of whether the game is worth your money. TRY THE DEMO!So, Towns. Oh boy, where to begin...This game is not a game for casual play. It's not a traditional game (although I will always believe it helped pave the way for an emerging genre) like most people will expect, and it's not most peoples' defenition of "easy".It's a game where you get out what you put in, and then some. But the catch is, the "and then some" is an exponential value. After a while, you realise that you've gone from mildly interested, to challenged, to excited, to inspired, to totally hooked. Now, in all fairness, the initial challenge is steep. Like I said, it's not an easy game, it's not pick-up-and-play-and-eventually-win.  In fact, Towns is designed to encourage experimentation and multiple approaches. There are no unlocks, it's quite possible to take your first town through the whole game and reach the "end"... but to get there, you'll need to unlock your own creativity and disaster management skills. That takes practice, plain and simple. But like any hobby, after that initial investment the first wave of reward convinces you to keep going, and after that it just gets better and better.Towns gets a lot of flak. Partly that's because it is genuinely lacking in content - at least, compared to what the content was obviously intended to be. However, I'm convinced that the flak is only spat so vigorously because Towns forces players to take a look at themselves and their own play style. In my view, a lot of the complaints are based off of the horrible realisation that some people just can't get their heads around the new strategies required to do well at this game. Because Towns is a game of strategy. It takes a keen perception and a lot of understanding to see the strategy in all its layers, but there is an underlying logic that is oh so satisfying to crack.That's not to say this is a game only for super-nerds. Rather, it requires a bit of patience and a bit of humour, plus a healthy curiosity. The patterns are simple enough once you spot them, and infinitely scaleable - that's the beauty of this game. Once you crack one challenge, you can expand and expand that solution and take the same basic logic into other challenges. That's not attractive to some players, but for others it's an absolute joy.Fortunately, there's a free demo - so you can see for yourself whether you enjoy that challenge or not. I wholeheartedly reccomend this game to anyone who is prepared to invest the time and open themselves to the experience. It's not what everyone will enjoy, but those who enjoy it will enjoy it a lot. If you're sick of the instant-gratification games, the ones with no substance or originality; if you just want to deeply engage with a challenge and figure it out; if you're the kind of person who thinks "gah, this is so complex... I love it, how do I solve this?", then Towns may well be one of the games you never entirely forget.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												Update: Abandoned now. It is what it is. Not exactly broken but neither finished as such. There are other games instead. Sorry.A rather cute sandbox game set in medieval time. The graphics is really nice retro. It is in a 45 degree turned isomettric view. This is also the low-point of it, it can't be turned that I know of. The menues are in the tiniest format, it's as easy to delete a game as it it to load it. That said, the menues inside the game are much better. Which is where the main production value seems to have been spent.The sound is very nice, slightly reminiscent of Settlers, the very first game, in the mood at least. I wouldn't say it's intrusive but you won't remember it either, which to me is a good point for game music.The actual game is fairly straight up management with the added fun of actual being able to lose quickly. The learning curve is steep, not overly but it will take a few games to get it like you want it. The management increases over time as you gain more people living in your town.You are very much victim of circumstances with this game. Sometimes you find iron at the surface, sometimes there is none to save your life. The caravans are an offset but dreaming of gold statues after a few hours, you've really struck gold. This makes every game a new challenge which is nice. Pretty much as Civilization was.The main thing to say about this game is that it's a time thief. You constantly look for the next thing you'll 'just do before quitting'. It sort of reminds you of minecraft in that aspect.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 27, 2013
												You'll hate yourself for playing this game. You really will. You see, this entire game revolves around using an annoying UI to control villagers with an intensely annoying AI to handle logistics poorly and theoretically command them to eventually get around to doing the things you'd like to do. Sort of like Majesty, if you had to build your buildings from scratch, the only part of them that was technically necessary outside of aesthetics was the floor and your kingdom had a rule of law that all new citizens born in the nation must be dropped on their head.You start out with about 11 morons to shepherd around, gradually kit them out in safety harnesses and protective helmets so that they'll be safe when you shove them out the door and hope that you'll lose as few as possible. Eventually you start getting heroes and such that you can use to explore the dungeons that extend deeper and deeper into the map and who protect your village from the increasingly difficult sieges laid by enemies, which can feel satisfying as hell to watch them fight after getting used to your moron brigade's perpetual failure.This is also one of those games where you open a wiki while you play, just so you know. Otherwise your village will completely and totally fail because the only way to get new villagers depends on the happiness of the village, which is designed in a way that either you intentionally build your village with them in mind, or else you die and start over.I dumped about thirty hours into it over the course of a week, then didn't touch it again afterward. That's pretty much the type of game this is.EDIT: About a year later, coming back to this review I'm changing my review to negative and adjusting the sarcastic-praise slightly. The game is still fun (and from playing it a bit more, the AI is less moronic than I recalled), and the UI is tolerable now that I remember how it works (though it's still not good). That said, you shouldn't buy this game. Buying it supports the developer, and he abandoned it without shame. If you want to play it, by all means do so, just don't give the developer money in order to do that. I'll leave figuring out how to obtain the game without paying the absent dev up to you, but that's my suggestion.
